commit_message:
Hyper-V: Fixes disk overhead claim issue

For each started VM, Hyper-V creates a VM memory file on the local
disk. The size of the file is the same as the size of the VM's
memory amount.

Implements the mentioned method in HyperVDriver.

Change-Id: Id40219dae96c0f7e60a86c0ed76fa08cea608aec
Closes-Bug: #1505681
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova refs/changes/07/246307/4 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: def estimate_instance_overhead(self, instance_info): # NOTE(claudiub): When an instance starts, Hyper-V creates a VM memory # file on the local disk. The file size is the same as the VM's amount # of memory. return {'memory_mb': 0, 'disk_gb': instance_info.memory_mb // units.Ki}

commit_message:
Add CI scripts for full deploy and images jobs

This simply copies what we have in JJB into in-tree scripts.
After this merges, we can change the JJB to consume these
scripts. This makes it much easier to change what is run in
CI, since we can get actual feedback on a patch that changes
CI.

It also combines promote and gate jobs into a single script
each. This will dramatically simplify the CI JJB.

Change-Id: I9600c773b3c7194d525b35b4acb502c5eea15323
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/tripleo-quickstart refs/changes/90/320490/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: #!/bin/bash # CI test that runs quickstart.sh to do a full deploy # Usage: full-deploy.sh <release> <build_system> <topology> RELEASE=$1 BUILD_SYS=$2 TOPOLOGY=$3 set -eux # (trown) This is so that we ensure seperate ssh sockets for # concurrent jobs. Without this, two jobs running in parallel # would try to use the same undercloud-stack socket. socketdir=$(mktemp -d /tmp/sockXXXXXX) export ANSIBLE_SSH_CONTROL_PATH=$socketdir/%%h-%%r bash $WORKSPACE/tripleo-quickstart/quickstart.sh \ --tags all \ --undercloud-image-url "http://artifacts.ci.centos.org/artifacts/rdo/images/$RELEASE/$BUILD_SYS/testing/undercloud.qcow2" \ --config $WORKSPACE/tripleo-quickstart/playbooks/centosci/$TOPOLOGY.yml \ --working-dir $WORKSPACE/ \ --no-clone \ $VIRTHOST $RELEASE

commit_message:
Compute: Adds driver disk_gb instance overhead estimation

For each started VM, Hyper-V creates a VM memory file on the local
disk. The size of the file is the same as the size of the VM's
memory amount.

Adds 'disk_gb' field in the dictionary returned by
nova.virt.driver.ComputeDriver.estimate_instance_overhead.

Updates ResourceTracker to create Claims using the new overhead.

DocImpact: driver API changed to include instances disk overhead.

Change-Id: Idd55d8c8cb19fe1eb9662021a483cee4051f1d1f
Partial-Bug: #1505681
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova refs/changes/83/234283/4 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # get the overhead required to build this instance: LOG.debug("Disk overhead for %(flavor)d GB instance; %(overhead)d " "GB", {'flavor': instance_ref.root_gb, 'overhead': overhead['disk_gb']}) LOG.debug("Disk overhead for %(flavor)d GB instance; %(overhead)d " "GB", {'flavor': instance_ref.root_gb, 'overhead': overhead['disk_gb']}) disk_usage = usage.get('root_gb', 0) disk_usage += overhead['disk_gb'] self.compute_node.local_gb_used += sign * disk_usage
deleted_lines: # get memory overhead required to build this instance: self.compute_node.local_gb_used += sign * usage.get('root_gb', 0)

subject: Drop use of resolve_address
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2016-05-23 08:49:19.000000000', 'files': ['unit_tests/test_neutron_ovs_context.py', 'templates/juno/metadata_agent.ini', 'hooks/neutron_ovs_context.py', 'templates/icehouse/metadata_agent.ini'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/charm-neutron-openvswitch/commit/4cfdc89c56663d1db4a9f147e62fb1a59e3fceb1', 'message': "Drop use of resolve_address

The shared secret context makes use of 'resolve_address' to
resolve the local_ip address of the unit; the resulting
value is not actually used in the metadata_agent.ini template
and breaks under Juju 2.0, where resolve_address attempts
to use network-get to resolve the public endpoint of the
service using extra bindings (which are not relevant for this
charm).

Drop use of resolve address and tidy templates; the default
127.0.0.1 address is fine for accessing the Nova Metadata
service from the Neutron Metadata agent proxy.

Change-Id: I03fc6d1c7c8ca832b02a7df5b1666c04aaecc589
Close-Bug: 1580271
"}]
commit_message:
Drop use of resolve_address

The shared secret context makes use of 'resolve_address' to
resolve the local_ip address of the unit; the resulting
value is not actually used in the metadata_agent.ini template
and breaks under Juju 2.0, where resolve_address attempts
to use network-get to resolve the public endpoint of the
service using extra bindings (which are not relevant for this
charm).

Drop use of resolve address and tidy templates; the default
127.0.0.1 address is fine for accessing the Nova Metadata
service from the Neutron Metadata agent proxy.

commit_message:
Add Challenges in Falcon.HTTP_Unauthorized

One of the breaking changes for falcon 1.0.0 is that HTTPUnauthorized
initializer now requires an additional argument, 'challenges': a server
returning a 401 must include a WWW-Authenticate header field containing
at least one challenge.

Change-Id: I88107c4093024e96ade8a5da0e70d0fb1ec58c42

commit_message:
clarify language about expectations for cycle-with-intermediary releases

During Mitaka we had some cycle-with-intermediary projects surprised
that the release team wanted them to produce releases at the end of the
cycle. This change expands the existing language to clarify that
expectation.

Change-Id: I673f0d88511966361daad7a9943e0efc360b061e
Signed-off-by: Doug Hellmann <doug@doughellmann.com>
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/governance refs/changes/19/318319/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: * "release:cycle-with-intermediary" projects commit to produce a release near the end of the 6-month development cycle to be used with projects using the other cycle-based release models that are required to produce a release at that time.
deleted_lines: * "release:cycle-with-intermediary" projects commit to produce a release to match the end of the 6-month development cycle.

commit_message:
Update the deployment docs

This commit updates the deployment docs with missing sections on
configuring the DB access and the RSS configuration. With this all
the options in the configuration file should be documented now. We
should strive to keep the readme up to date as we add additional
configuration options.

Change-Id: Ifb4d6ad1f9adacbd5a3ab483d8d23063ba815c7b
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/openstack-health refs/changes/09/319309/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: Database Configuration ^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^ Depending on how your backend subunit2sql database is configured and how you've configured the WSGI app deployed you might want to adjust the access patterns used for querying the database. There are 3 options related to database access. The first is **mandatory**, `db_uri` is the sqlalchemy connection string for connecting to the database. The second option is `pool_size` which sets the size of the connection pool to use, the default being 20. This option is used to set the maxinum number of persistent connections allowed per process. It can be set to 0 to indicate there is no limit and -1 is used to disable pooling (which is normally a really bad idea). The last option is `pool_recycle` which is used to prevent the pool from using a connection which has passed a certain age. This is a value in seconds and it defaults to 3600 (1 hour) for more info about this option refer to the sqlalchemy documentation: `http://docs.sqlalchemy.org/en/latest/core/pooling.html#setting-pool-recycle <http://docs.sqlalchemy.org/en/latest/core/pooling.html#setting-pool-recycle>`_ RSS Configuration ^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^ There are certain API queries that return an RSS feed on the wire. As part of the events generated on these feed there are links to pages on the JS frontend. To generate the correct links you have to tell the api server the base url of the frontend. This is set with the `frontend_url` option and it defaults to 'http://status.openstack.org/openstack-health' the OpenStack community instance of OpenStack-Health.

commit_message:
test_port_security_macspoofing_port: Don't assume DHCP port

DHCP port is a detail of the reference implementation.
Non agent based implementations might not provide it.
Anyway, as the purpose of this test case is to test
port-security, not DHCP, it's better to avoid assuming
the existance of DHCP port.  Use an ordinary VM instead.

Closes-Bug: #1521224
Change-Id: I84a69c6b3d81218ba7811332d936cb891bdff353

commit_message:
BGP extension implementation(1st stage)

This patch includes following modifications.
* support bgp-speaker, bgp-peer and binding speaker and peer.
* add router_id parameter to bgp-speaker.
  (this parameter must be specified in 1st stage.)
* attached network and destination network in extra routes are
  showed as advertised routes.
* unit tests for bgp extension.
* create bgp-speaker without router is not implemented.
  (this limit will be lifted in 2nd patch.)

MidoNet plugin is different from upstream as follows.
* binding bgp-speaker to network is not supported in MidoNet.
* bgp-peer can relate to only one bgp-speaker in MidoNet.
* these parameters are ignored in MidoNet.
  - advertise_floating_ip_host_routes
  - advertise_tenant_networks

Change-Id: I8fb421459876346e3630c0f6661795e6517c7ce0
Closes-Bug: #1554962

commit_message:
NetApp: Remove type checks from manage workflow

In a previous release, Cinder began routing manage API calls
through the scheduler to validate the suitability of the
specified pool for a volume being managed. The NetApp
drivers no longer need to do this check, which is part
of the storage service catalog code that we're replacing
during Newton.

Partially implements: blueprint replace-netapp-cdot-ssc-module

Change-Id: I567b2a95844a5be9291eac4b7d256dcb997e5626

commit_message:
Add quota tests in api tests.

The quotas tests in the case of create resources over limit value
are not covered enough in unit tests/functional tests.

This patch include test case of api functional tests.

Change-Id: Ibde1cdff068ae8ac130d05143d53b6b783ad0fa3
Closes-bug: #1567743

You may obtain # a copy of the License at # # http://www.apache.org/licenses/LICENSE-2.0 # # Unless required by applicable law or agreed to in writing, software # distributed under the License is distributed on an "AS IS" BASIS, WITHOUT # WARRANTIES OR CONDITIONS OF ANY KIND, either express or implied. See the # License for the specific language governing permissions and limitations # under the License. from tempest.lib.common.utils import data_utils from tempest.lib import exceptions as lib_exc from tempest import test from neutron.tests.tempest.api import base from neutron.tests.tempest import config CONF = config.CONF class QuotasAdminNegativeTestJSON(base.BaseAdminNetworkTest): @classmethod @test.requires_ext(extension="quotas", service="network") def resource_setup(cls): super(QuotasAdminNegativeTestJSON, cls).resource_setup() # Add a tenant to conduct the test test_tenant = data_utils.rand_name('test_tenant_') test_description = data_utils.rand_name('desc_') tenant = cls.identity_admin_client.create_tenant( name=test_tenant, description=test_description)['tenant'] cls.tenant_id = tenant['id'] @test.attr(type='negative') @test.idempotent_id('952f9b24-9156-4bdc-90f3-682a3d4302f0') def test_create_network_when_quotas_is_full(self): self._setup_quotas('network', 1) net_args = {'tenant_id': self.tenant_id} net = self.admin_client.create_network(**net_args)['network'] self.addCleanup(self.admin_client.delete_network, net['id']) self.assertRaises(lib_exc.Conflict, self.admin_client.create_network, **net_args) @test.attr(type='negative') @test.idempotent_id('0b7f99e3-9f77-45ce-9a89-b39a184de618') def test_create_subnet_when_quotas_is_full(self): self._setup_quotas('subnet', 1) net_args = {'tenant_id': self.tenant_id} net = self.admin_client.create_network(**net_args)['network'] self.addCleanup(self.admin_client.delete_network, net['id']) cidr = CONF.network.project_network_cidr subnet_args = {'tenant_id': self.tenant_id, 'network_id': net['id'], 'cidr': cidr, 'ip_version': '4'} subnet = self.admin_client.create_subnet(**subnet_args)['subnet'] self.addCleanup(self.admin_client.delete_subnet, subnet['id']) self.assertRaises(lib_exc.Conflict, self.admin_client.create_subnet, **subnet_args) @test.attr(type='negative') @test.idempotent_id('fe20d9f9-346c-4a20-bbfa-d9ca390f4dc6') def test_create_port_when_quotas_is_full(self): self._setup_quotas('port', 1) ext_net_id = CONF.network.public_network_id port_args = {'tenant_id': self.tenant_id, 'network_id': ext_net_id} port = self.admin_client.create_port(**port_args)['port'] self.addCleanup(self.admin_client.delete_port, port['id']) self.assertRaises(lib_exc.Conflict, self.admin_client.create_port, **port_args) @test.attr(type='negative') @test.idempotent_id('bb1e9c3c-7e6f-41f1-b579-63dbc655ecb7') def test_create_router_when_quotas_is_full(self): self._setup_quotas('router', 1) name = data_utils.rand_name('test_router_') router_args = {'tenant_id': self.tenant_id} router = self.admin_client.create_router( name, True, **router_args)['router'] self.addCleanup(self.admin_client.delete_router, router['id']) self.assertRaises(lib_exc.Conflict, self.admin_client.create_router, name, True, **router_args) @test.attr(type='negative') @test.idempotent_id('5c924ff7-b7a9-474f-92a3-dbe0f976ec13') def test_create_security_group_when_quotas_is_full(self): sg_args = {'tenant_id': self.tenant_id} num = 1 # avoid a number that is made by default try: sg_list = self.admin_client.list_security_groups( tenant_id=self.tenant_id)['security_groups'] num = len([sg_list[n]['id'] for n in range(0, len(sg_list))]) + 1 except lib_exc.NotFound: pass self._setup_quotas('security_group', num) sg = self.admin_client.create_security_group( **sg_args)['security_group'] self.addCleanup(self.admin_client.delete_security_group, sg['id']) self.assertRaises(lib_exc.Conflict, self.admin_client.create_security_group, **sg_args) @test.attr(type='negative') @test.idempotent_id('b7143480-6118-4ed4-be38-1b6f15f30d05') def test_create_security_group_rule_when_quotas_is_full(self): sg_args = {'tenant_id': self.tenant_id} sg = self.admin_client.create_security_group( **sg_args)['security_group'] self.addCleanup(self.admin_client.delete_security_group, sg['id']) num = 1 # avoid a number that is made by default try: sg_rule_list = self.admin_client.list_security_group_rules( tenant_id=self.tenant_id)['security_group_rules'] num = len([sg_rule_list[n]['id'] for n in range(0, len(sg_rule_list))]) + 1 except lib_exc.NotFound: pass self._setup_quotas('security_group_rule', num) sg_rule_args = {'tenant_id': self.tenant_id, 'security_group_id': sg['id'], 'direction': 'ingress'} sg_rule = self.admin_client.create_security_group_rule( **sg_rule_args)['security_group_rule'] self.addCleanup( self.admin_client.delete_security_group_rule, sg_rule['id']) self.assertRaises(lib_exc.Conflict, self.admin_client.create_security_group_rule, **sg_rule_args) @test.attr(type='negative') @test.idempotent_id('d00fe5bb-9db8-4e1a-9c31-490f52897e6f') def test_create_floatingip_when_quotas_is_full(self): self._setup_quotas('floatingip', 1) ext_net_id = CONF.network.public_network_id fip_args = {'tenant_id': self.tenant_id, 'floating_network_id': ext_net_id} fip = self.admin_client.create_floatingip(**fip_args)['floatingip'] self.addCleanup(self.admin_client.delete_floatingip, fip['id']) self.assertRaises(lib_exc.Conflict, self.admin_client.create_floatingip, **fip_args) def _setup_quotas(self, resource, num): new_quotas = {resource: num} # Change quotas for tenant self.admin_client.update_quotas(self.tenant_id, **new_quotas) self.addCleanup(self._cleanup_quotas, self.tenant_id) def _cleanup_quotas(self, project_id): # Try to clean up the resources. If it fails, then # assume that everything was already deleted, so # it is OK to continue. try: self.admin_client.reset_quotas(project_id) except lib_exc.NotFound: pass

subject: Fix existing metadata display in metadata widget
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2016-05-16 11:56:32.000000000', 'files': ['horizon/static/framework/widgets/metadata/tree/tree.service.js', 'horizon/static/framework/widgets/metadata/tree/metadata-tree.html'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/horizon/commit/b398571dceaf990a1c38492a1134ec08312f1f4c', 'message': 'Fix existing metadata display in metadata widget

The metadata widget displays both available and existing
metadata for a given resource. For example, on images
you can click "Update Metadata" and it will show you
all of the metadata that you can apply on the left
and all the metadata that is already on the image
on the right. This is basically a vertical transfer
table.

Available metadata is structure as a tree and the
actual properties are "leaf" nodes. When you
transfer from left to right it is only supposed to
show actual properties and not the "folders". These
are the leaf nodes.

This was handled by filtering with the built in
angular filter [0] and was relying on a property
"leaf" to be set to null. However, in doing research,
I found that the way angular handles null in filtering
changes between angular versions [0]. I tried various
options and could not seem to make it work, so this
patch changes from setting leaf from null to false.

This fix removes the console log, but also removes
an issue where sometimes you couldn't remove metadata
item that had previously been saved.

[0] http://stackoverflow.com/questions/18644412/angularjs-filter-not-null

Change-Id: Ib93890d40b8103c378bb806015e50f3baa2b4fc6
Closes-Bug: 1572686
(cherry picked from commit 6ad36e0e5706f0b0a89269ccfa694dee82fd712c)
'}]
commit_message:
Fix existing metadata display in metadata widget

The metadata widget displays both available and existing
metadata for a given resource. For example, on images
you can click "Update Metadata" and it will show you
all of the metadata that you can apply on the left
and all the metadata that is already on the image
on the right. This is basically a vertical transfer
table.

Available metadata is structure as a tree and the
actual properties are "leaf" nodes. When you
transfer from left to right it is only supposed to
show actual properties and not the "folders". These
are the leaf nodes.

This was handled by filtering with the built in
angular filter [0] and was relying on a property
"leaf" to be set to null. However, in doing research,
I found that the way angular handles null in filtering
changes between angular versions [0]. I tried various
options and could not seem to make it work, so this
patch changes from setting leaf from null to false.

This fix removes the console log, but also removes
an issue where sometimes you couldn't remove metadata
item that had previously been saved.

[0] http://stackoverflow.com/questions/18644412/angularjs-filter-not-null

Change-Id: Ib93890d40b8103c378bb806015e50f3baa2b4fc6
Closes-Bug: 1572686
(cherry picked from commit 6ad36e0e5706f0b0a89269ccfa694dee82fd712c)
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/horizon refs/changes/63/316763/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: <li ng-repeat="item in existingList = (ctrl.tree.flatTree | filter:{$:ctrl.filterText.existing, added:true, leaf:'!false'} | orderBy:'leaf.name')"
deleted_lines: <li ng-repeat="item in existingList = (ctrl.tree.flatTree | filter:{$:ctrl.filterText.existing, added:true, leaf:'!null'} | orderBy:'leaf.name')"

If the assertRaises(...) fails (e.g if an exception is not raised)
then the test will exit right away and the method call to reset the
environment is not executed.

We should use the addCleanup(...) mechanism to be sure that the cleanup

commit_message:
Add cleanup in identity/test_users_negative.py

If the assertRaises(...) fails (e.g if an exception is not raised)
then the test will exit right away and the method call to reset the
environment is not executed.

We should use the addCleanup(...) mechanism to be sure that the cleanup
happens regardless of the status of the test.

Change-Id: I43cec136691bb1b39b01756a2a4139abf3d2d51b

commit_message:
Colocation constraint always has master role.

All colocation contraint are created with master role.  This is because
currently the code test the if @resource[:master_role] is true.  As the
parameter return the symbol :false, this is considered as a true value.

This fix the problem by making sure the parameter is cast into a
TrueClass, FalseClass.

Closes-Bug: 1583792

Change-Id: Ic00e49a71130b7f00f33a5f698b2de6e5608dcce

commit_message:
Make sure ConfigType is an abstract class

Use the abstract class to ensure that all types provide the
method _formatter.

Change-Id: Ifa2e9ca7b91d71887d2bd4ce2e6bb21c2f616722

commit_message:
Add F5 Onboard and Deploy Heat Templates to Catalog Edit

Added HOT templates to the catalog for the onboarding of
F5 BIG-IP images and the deployment of those images
in standalone mode for 2 and 3 interface topologies.

Change-Id: I2dd2a1da12cd06e571ec820b01159a51edd3449a
Implements: blueprint add-f5-to-catalog
Signed-off-by: Shawn Wormke <shawn@f5.com>

commit_message:
Pagination fix for ORM

Commit fixes pagination with ORM.
Offset and limit are used in sub query
that retrieves alarm ids.

Closes-Bug: 1579625

commit_message:
Add a tool to list all oslo projects (using gerrit APIs)

This tool will scan gerrit for projects that are managed
by oslo-core and output a json file containing these projects
for usage by other (future) tools that can then use this file
as input.

Change-Id: I412e89b31eade565622c4eb44fe95d03fcb9323f

commit_message:
Use JUJU_MODEL_UUID for Juju 2.0

Juju 2.0 renames the environment variable JUJU_ENV_UUID
to JUJU_MODEL_UUID; use this environment variable as a
fallback if JUJU_ENV_UUID is not set to support Juju 2.0,
whilst continuing to provide support for Juju < 2.0.

Change-Id: I0e9ebbe59032e3d15864ee1f9bd49b404b339a3b
Closes-Bug: 1572575
(cherry picked from commit fc1943af8fff3c191e51857445f61e6ec4e54d85)

To enable:

commit_message:
Enable notification messaging pools

Adds a 'notification_pool' option in the [listener] configuration
section. This is an alternative to adding a separate topic that will be
recommended for the Newton release following more testing; for now it is
an optional alternative.

To enable:

  [listener]
  notifications_pool = searchlight-listener

You will see a rabbitmq queue named searchlight-listener. Note that your
topic must match the service notifications_topic setting, whether it be
the default of 'notifications' or 'searchlight_indexer'.

Conflicts:
	doc/source/authoring-plugins.rst
	test-scripts/listener.py

Closes-Bug: #1583215
Change-Id: Ie40876e88059d0326efa0b4abaa76b8b64f0b86b

added_lines: #!/usr/bin/env python # Copyright (c) 2016 Hewlett-Packard Enterprise Development Company, L.P. # # Licensed under the Apache License, Version 2.0 (the "License"); # you may not use this file except in compliance with the License. # You may obtain a copy of the License at # # http://www.apache.org/licenses/LICENSE-2.0 # # Unless required by applicable law or agreed to in writing, software # distributed under the License is distributed on an "AS IS" BASIS, # WITHOUT WARRANTIES OR CONDITIONS OF ANY KIND, either express or # implied. # See the License for the specific language governing permissions and # limitations under the License. import json import os from oslo_config import cfg import oslo_messaging import sys import time try: import urlparse as urlparse except ImportError: import urllib.parse as urlparse topic = 'searchlight_indexer' password = os.environ.get('RABBIT_PASSWORD', os.environ.get('OS_PASSWORD')) host = urlparse.urlparse(os.environ.get('OS_AUTH_URL')).hostname username = os.environ.get('RABBIT_USER', 'stackrabbit') class EP(object): def info(self, ctxt, publisher_id, event_type, payload, metadata): all_locals = locals() all_locals.pop('self') print(json.dumps(all_locals)) def error(self, ctxt, publisher_id, event_type, payload, metadata): all_locals = locals() all_locals.pop('self') print(json.dumps(all_locals)) def main(): if len(sys.argv) < 2: print("Supply an exchange") sys.exit(0) exchange = sys.argv[1] pool = sys.argv[2] if len(sys.argv) > 2 else None transport = oslo_messaging.get_transport( cfg.CONF, url='rabbit://%s:%s@%s' % (username, password, host)) targets = [oslo_messaging.Target(topic=topic, exchange=exchange)] endpoints = [EP()] oslo_listener = oslo_messaging.get_notification_listener( transport, targets, endpoints, pool=pool, executor='threading') try: print("Started") oslo_listener.start() while True: time.sleep(1) except KeyboardInterrupt: print("Stopping") oslo_listener.stop() oslo_listener.wait() if __name__ == '__main__': main()

fallback if JUJU_ENV_UUID is not set to support Juju 2.0,

commit_message:
Clarify which projects are meant to use the ironic-lib

This patch is updating the README file to clarify that only projects
under the Ironic governance should be consuming this library.

Change-Id: Ie1430c955e44311bbe5d60503ee146ce1601612e

commit_message:
Split functionality out of main

This commit splits out the actual output generation functionality from
the main function. It also adds parameters for specifying a stdin and
stdout file object. This enables external access to the output
generation within python, which could be useful for integrating
subunit-trace output with your own test runner.

Change-Id: Id9fc13b9b70c5b2cc47b48eee6426e7e312eff7f
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/os-testr refs/changes/67/283667/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/monasca-analytics refs/changes/57/315157/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # Domain Specific Language (DSL) for configuration handling A simple DSL language, accessible from a command line tool, has been implemented in order to manage configurations in an easier way. This section explains what operations are available, and how to use them. > Note: Please refer to [Monasca/Configuration](configuration.md) to understand the structure of the configuration. ## Usage * Start Mananas DSL tool ```bash python $MONANAS_HOME/config_dsl.py ``` After running this command, a simple empty orchestration configuration will be created, which you can then modify running operations according to your needs. ## Config manipulation operations You can run the following operations from the DSL command line in order to create, remove, connect, disconnect and modify components in the configuration. ###Create component * Create a component and assign it to a variable ```bash >> A = IPTablesSource ``` This command adds a new source of type IPTablesSource to the configuration, assigning it its default configuration. It links the source component to variable A, and returns a unique ID. You can either use the variable or the ID in order to reference the instance of IPTablesSource you just created. ### Remove component * Remove a component using its ID or variable name ```bash >> rm A ``` This command removes the component referenced by A from the configuration. The parameter can either be a variable or an ID associated to a component in the configuration. The component will only be removed if it is not connected to any other component. ### Connect components * Connect two components in the configuration ```bash >> A -> B ``` This command connects the component referenced by A with the component referenced by B. Both A and B can be variables or IDs, and the connection is directional from A to B. The connection will only be performed if the components exist and their connection is allowed. For example, connecting a source with an ingestor is allowed, but connecting a source with a voter is not. ### Disconnect components * Disconnect two components in the configuration ```bash >> A !-> B ``` This command disconnects the component A from component B. Both A and B can be variables or IDs, and the connection is directional from A to B. If the connection didn't exist, nothing will happen. ### Modify component * Modify values of the configuration of a component ```bash >> A.params.subparam1.subparam2 = value ``` This command modifies the value of the configuration parameter at the end of the path defined by the dot notation. The configuration is validated before being modified, hence if the modification results in an invalid configuration, it will not be performed. A can either be a variable or an ID. ## Config presentation operations You can run the following operations from the DSL command line in order to view the current configuration, sub-configurations, and available components that you can instantiate. ### Print * Print the full configuration ```bash >> print ``` This command displays the full configuration in json format to your screen. * Print component type sub-configuration ```bash >> print connections ``` If you pass a parameter to the print command that corresponds to a component type, or, in general, a first level key of the configuration, only the relevant sub-configuration that you selected will be displayed to your screen. * Print a particular component sub-configuration ```bash >> print A ``` If you pass a parameter to the print command that corresponds to a variable or an ID associated to a particular component, only its configuration will be displayed to your screen. ### List * Print all available components ```bash >> list ``` This command displays all available components that you can add to your configuration, organized by type. * Print all available components of a particular type ```bash >> list smls ``` If you pass the type as a parameter to the list command, only the available components of that type will be listed. ## Config storage operations You can run the following operations from the DSL command line in order to load and save configurations from/to files. ### Load * Load a configuration from a file ```bash >> load filename ``` This command loads the configuration stored in the file 'filename', overriding the existing configuration you were handling before. ### Save * Save a configuration to a file ```bash >> save filename ``` This command saves the configuration being currently handled to the file 'filename', overriding the file if it existed before. * Save a configuration to the last file ```bash >> save ``` If no parameter is provided, the save operation saves the current configuration being handled to the last file you loaded from or saved to.

revisions:

Currently we expect amount field to be an integer, but it can
also be a string or a YAQL expression. This does not allow us

commit_message:
Fix strategy amount field validation to support arbitrary objects

Currently we expect amount field to be an integer, but it can
also be a string or a YAQL expression. This does not allow us
to calculate the degree of parallelism for things that should
be run one by one or in parallel depending on cluster state
transition

Change-Id: I7fa767d267404582a48d1cc9ea371d8c7bf51161
Partial-bug: #1565885
(cherry picked from commit d45960200a41158f1293d917f9a7eef1dc4c25d4)

added_lines: YAQL_EXP = { '$schema': 'http://json-schema.org/draft-04/schema#', 'type': 'object', 'required': ['yaql_exp'], 'properties': { 'yaql_exp': {'type': 'string'}, } } 'amount': {'oneOf': [ {'type': 'integer'}, YAQL_EXP ] }

commit_message:
Seperate regex builder logic into a seperate module

The regex building logic is independently useful and will likely start
to be used in other places. This commits splits it out from the ostestr
cli and makes it an independent module that just contains the pieces
necessary for building a selection regex.

Change-Id: Ic8494d0f54357fdafd650b40219e6ad7fd5a65ad

commit_message:
Added transport URL example from oslo.messaging docs

It is worth noting that one can specify several hosts on the
transport_url configuration options from oslo.messaging both for RPCs
and for notifications. So it will be useful for users of the module
to see the format.

Change-Id: Ia39f2e4e1ff3f02f1b14b56f985fae98446c6c10
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/puppet-oslo refs/changes/22/320222/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # Transport URLs take the form:: # transport://user:pass@host1:port[,hostN:portN]/virtual_host

commit_message:
Add scrolling to the projector selector

Adds a scrollbar to the project selector for larger screens. This isn't
needed for smaller sizes, as it already scrolls.

Co-Authored-By: Rob Cresswell <robert.cresswell@outlook.com>
Change-Id: Ib03eafccd4725af94556286f1f541a9e7cde96e4
Closes-Bug: #1498039
(cherry picked from commit 1644a0eee407ba59ed07927cb41783e5c04f0c18)
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/horizon refs/changes/54/320054/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: // This is the max height for the domain/project selector in the top nav. After // this point, it will scroll. $context-selector-max-height: calc(99vh - #{$navbar-height}) !default;

  vm.router.out_dropped_sec
  vm.router.in_errors_sec
  vm.router.out_errors_sec

The 'vm' metrics are posted to the operations project, and
the others to the customer projects.  All credit for the
content for this module goes to Sean Lynn -- not Brad Klein :).

Change-Id: I7c446d85f4d9854d8aba0c6216c2b88a8ef5ae05

commit_message:
Add plugin for gathering ovs virtual router statistics

This plugin will operate much like the libvirt plugin, by
publishing the following virtual router metrics:

  vrouter.in_[bits|bytes]_sec
  vrouter.out_[bits|bytes]_sec
  vrouter.in_packets_sec
  vrouter.out_packets_sec
  vrouter.in_dropped_sec
  vrouter.out_dropped_sec
  vrouter.in_errors_sec
  vrouter.out_errors_sec

  ovs.vrouter.in_[bits|bytes]_sec
  ovs.vrouter.out_[bits|bytes]_sec
  ovs.vrouter.in_packets_sec
  ovs.vrouter.out_packets_sec
  ovs.vrouter.in_dropped_sec
  ovs.vrouter.out_dropped_sec
  ovs.vrouter.in_errors_sec
  ovs.vrouter.out_errors_sec

The 'ovs' metrics are posted to the operations project, and
the others to the customer projects.  All credit for the
content for this module goes to Sean Lynn -- not Brad Klein :).

Change-Id: I7c446d85f4d9854d8aba0c6216c2b88a8ef5ae05
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/monasca-agent refs/changes/21/306621/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: #!/bin/env python import datetime import json import logging import os import re import subprocess import time from neutronclient.v2_0 import client as neutron_client from monasca_agent.collector.checks import AgentCheck METRICS = {"router.out_bytes_sec": "tx_bps", "router.in_bytes_sec": "rx_bps"} """Monasca Agent interface for ovs router metrics""" class OvsCheck(AgentCheck): """This check gathers ovs router metrics WARNING: the user that monasca-agent runs as must have sudo access for the '/usr/bin/ovs-vsctl' command sudo access is not required when running monasca-agent as root (not recommended) example /etc/sudoers entry (assumes monasca-agent runs as user mon-agent): mon-agent ALL=(ALL) NOPASSWD:/usr/bin/ovs-vsctl """ def __init__(self, name, init_config, agent_config, instances=None): AgentCheck.__init__(self, name, init_config, agent_config, instances=[{}]) def check(self, instance): dims_base = self._set_dimensions({'service': 'neutron', 'component': 'vm'}, instance) self.log.info("Collecting OVS router metrics") if not self._can_sudo(): raise Exception('The monasca-agent user does not have sudo access') wait_time = 10.0 self.log.debug("* Retrieving first data set") time1 = time.time() interface_data1 = self._get_ovs_data() if not interface_data1: self.log.info("* No OVS data to report") return self.log.debug("* Waiting ~%0.2f seconds (working in the meantime)" % wait_time) self.log.debug(" Retrieving Neutron port data") nc = self._get_neutron_client() all_ports_data = nc.list_ports() all_ports_data = all_ports_data['ports'] self.log.debug(" Retrieving Neutron router data") all_routers_data = nc.list_routers() all_routers_data = all_routers_data['routers'] time2 = time.time() remaining_time = time2 - time1 if remaining_time < wait_time: time.sleep(wait_time - remaining_time) self.log.debug("* Retrieving second data set") interface_data2 = self._get_ovs_data() time3 = time.time() # Used to calculate bandwidth rates delta_time = time3 - time1 self.log.info("* Time difference used is %0.2f seconds" % delta_time) ifx_deltas = {} for ifx in interface_data1: if re.match(r"^qg-", ifx): uuid = interface_data1[ifx]['external_ids']['iface-id'] ifx_deltas.update({ifx: {'port_uuid': uuid}}) # Use abs in case ovs data randomly resets to zero tx_bps = 8.0 / delta_time * \ abs(interface_data2[ifx]['statistics']['tx_bytes'] - interface_data1[ifx]['statistics']['tx_bytes']) rx_bps = 8.0 / delta_time * \ abs(interface_data2[ifx]['statistics']['rx_bytes'] - interface_data1[ifx]['statistics']['rx_bytes']) self.log.info("{} current values: tx_bytes: {} rx_bytes: {}". format(ifx, interface_data2[ifx]['statistics']['tx_bytes'], interface_data2[ifx]['statistics']['rx_bytes'])) ifx_deltas[ifx]['tx_bps'] = tx_bps ifx_deltas[ifx]['rx_bps'] = rx_bps for ifx, value in ifx_deltas.iteritems(): port_info = self._get_ostack_info_by_uuid(value['port_uuid'], all_ports_data) router_uuid = port_info['device_id'] router_info = self._get_ostack_info_by_uuid(router_uuid, all_routers_data) router_name = router_info['name'] tenant_id = router_info['tenant_id'] ifx_dimensions = {'resource_id': router_uuid, 'router_name': router_name } this_dimensions = dims_base.copy() this_dimensions.update(ifx_dimensions) for metric_name, idx in METRICS.iteritems(): # POST to customer project self.gauge(metric_name, value[idx], dimensions=this_dimensions, delegated_tenant=tenant_id) # POST to operations project with "vm." prefix self.gauge("vm.{0}".format(metric_name), value[idx], dimensions=this_dimensions) def _get_ovs_data(self): data_columns = ['name', 'external_ids', 'statistics', 'options'] cmd = 'sudo /usr/bin/ovs-vsctl --columns=name,external_ids,statistics,options --format=json --data=json list Interface' output = self._process_command(cmd) parsed_ovs_data = {} if not output: return parsed_ovs_data raw_ovs_json_data = json.loads(output) # There are multiple lines returned, one for each device for line in raw_ovs_json_data['data']: ifx_data = {} ifx_name = None # There is one entry in each line for every data_column # print "Row:" for column_num in range(0, len(data_columns)): # Two choices here, it's either a value or a (sub)map # If it's a value it becomes a key in the hierarchy if line[column_num][0] == "map": map_data = {} for value in line[column_num][1]: map_data.update({value[0]: value[1]}) ifx_data.update({data_columns[column_num]: map_data}) else: # In this specific case name (interface) is our main key # How this would generalize, I don't know. if data_columns[column_num] == "name": ifx_name = line[column_num] # Put the interface data in the main dictionary parsed_ovs_data.update({ifx_name: ifx_data}) return parsed_ovs_data def _get_ostack_info_by_uuid(self, uuid, all_data): for data in all_data: if data['id'] == uuid: return data return None def _get_neutron_client(self): return neutron_client.Client(username=self.init_config.get('admin_user'), password=self.init_config.get('admin_password'), tenant_name=self.init_config.get('admin_tenant_name'), auth_url=self.init_config.get('identity_uri'), endpoint_type='internalURL') def _run_command(self, command, input=None): self.log.debug("Executing command - {0}".format(command)) try: process = subprocess.Popen(command, shell=True, stdout=subprocess.PIPE, stderr=subprocess.PIPE, stdin=subprocess.PIPE) stdout, stderr = process.communicate(input=input) errcode = process.returncode self.log.debug('errcode - {0}, stdout - {1}, stderr - {2}'.format(errcode, stdout, stderr)) return errcode, stdout, stderr except Exception: self.log.error("Failure while executing command - {0}".format(command)) def _process_command(self, command): """Runs the command and returns json output """ try: errcode, stdout, stderr = self._run_command(command) cmd_output = '' for line in stdout: cmd_output = cmd_output + line return cmd_output except Exception as e: self.log.error('Failure while processing output - {0}'.format(e)) def _can_sudo(self): if os.geteuid() == 0: return True else: return 0 == os.system('setsid sudo -l > /dev/null')

commit_message:
Render the common role in the CLI

The common role was not being rendered so the kolla_ansible_toolbox
image variable was never being replaced.

Closes-bug: #1584921

Change-Id: I76713fb059bebae96bf9f0fcb011a514e295eb6a
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/kolla-kubernetes refs/changes/97/320097/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: common_ansible_roles = os.path.join(dir, 'ansible/roles', 'common', 'defaults', 'main.yml') common_local_ansible_roles = os.path.join(local_dir, 'roles', 'common', 'defaults', 'main.yml') if dir and os.path.exists(common_ansible_roles): jinja_utils.yaml_jinja_render(common_ansible_roles, jvars) elif dir and os.path.exists(common_local_ansible_roles): jinja_utils.yaml_jinja_render(common_local_ansible_roles, jvars) else: LOG.warning('Unable to load %s', common_ansible_roles)

release notes

commit_message:
Add spec for push notification refactor

Adds a spec to change the method we use to get
information from the server to the agents. Rather
than the server notifying the agent to call the server,
we can just put the relevant data in the notification
itself to improve scalability and reliability.

The bulk of this spec is dealing with the message ordering
guarantee we will need to accomplish this. It also has
some work items to help improve our current pattern.

Related-Bug: #1516195
Change-Id: I3af200ad84483e6e1fe619d516ff20bc87041f7c
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/neutron-specs refs/changes/95/225995/5 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: .. This work is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 3.0 Unported License. http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/3.0/legalcode ============================= Push Notifications for Agents ============================= Include the URL of your launchpad blueprint: https://blueprints.launchpad.net/neutron/+spec/push-notifications Our agents currently call the Neutron server at any time and ask for information (e.g. L3 agent's hosted routers, L2 agent's tunnel endpoints, DHCP agent's serviced ports). These queries can be triggered in response to failures to retrieve other information from the server, which quickly leads to stampeding herd scenarios where the agents completely DDoS the servers. This blueprint aims to address this issue by changing the pattern used to get information to the agents to a server-driven push style. Problem Description =================== An outage of a few agents and their recovery can lead to all of the agents drowning the Neutron servers in requests. The neutron servers then fail to respond in time, which results in more retry requests building up, leaving the entire system useless until operator intervention. This is caused by 3 problems: * Agent 'liveness' for scheduling/rescheduling purposes is based on state reports that use the same queue as calls that take a long time for the server to process. So the server will think an agent is down because the agent heartbeat is stuck in a queue behind a slow synchronization task. * The agents will give up after a short period of time on a request and retry the request or issue an even more expensive request (e.g. if syncronizing info for one item fails, a major issue is assumed so a request to sync all items is issued). So by the time the server finishes fulfilling a request, the client is no longer waiting for a response for that so it goes in the trash. As this compounds, it leaves the server processing a massive queue of requests that will likely not have listeners for the responses. * We don't make good use of notifications in all cases. There are times when we will send a notification to an agent to let it know something has changed. Then the agent has to turn around an make a call to the server to get the relevant details. This means a single L3 rescheduling event can result in N more calls to the server where N is the number of routers. If this event was already caused by the first problem, the same thing will happen when these 50 new requests trample the server some more. Proposed Change =============== Eliminate almost every RPC call that the agents currently make to the Neutron server to retrieve data. The idea is to have only one initial sync mechanism that an agent is allowed to call the server for, and then the rest is derived from the notifications sent on state changes. For the remaining calls, such as the initial sync and the agent-generated notifications (e.g. updating port status and binding info), we will need to set a high initial timeout and implement an exponential back-off mechanism. Data Model Impact ----------------- N/A REST API Impact --------------- N/A Security Impact --------------- N/A Notifications Impact -------------------- Making existing notifications significantly more data-rich. The hope here is to eliminate many of the RPC calls that each agent can make and force them do derive all state from notifications with one method of recovery that we can focus on optimizing. This section will be edited with the specific changes as we identify all of the issues during the implementation of this spec. Other End User Impact --------------------- N/A Performance Impact ------------------ Better scalability and performance for the Neutron server. Otherwise this will be pointless. IPv6 Impact ----------- N/A Other Deployer Impact --------------------- N/A - upgrade path will maintain normal N-1 backward compatibilty on the server Developer Impact ---------------- Need to change development guidelines to avoid the implementation of new direct server calls. Community Impact ---------------- Helps Neutron reference implementation scale and improves its stability. Alternatives ------------ Continue attempting to optimize each call after it is discovered that it causes the system to fail at large scale. Implementation ============== Assignee(s) ----------- Primary assignee: kevinbenton Work Items ---------- Work items or tasks -- break the feature up into the things that need to be done to implement it. Those parts might end up being done by different people, but we're mostly trying to understand the timeline for implementation. Dependencies ============ N/A Testing ======= I would like to add a 'RCP pain multiplier' option that just causes all calls to the neutron server to be duplicated that number of times. That way we can set it to something like 200 for the gate which will force us to make every call reasonably performant. Tempest Tests ------------- N/A Functional Tests ---------------- N/A API Tests --------- N/A Documentation Impact ==================== User Documentation ------------------ N/A Developer Documentation ----------------------- Devref guidelines on the pattern for getting information to agents and what the acceptability critieria are for calls to the server. References ========== N/A

commit_message:
Add Release notes for fixes backported to 0.2.1

Numerous event fixes and ElasticSearch 2.x fixes were
fixed and subsequently backported to stable/mitaka.
They didn't include release notes. This patch adds those.
It will need to be backported to stable/mitaka as well.

Change-Id: I344e9428a976cb3992f10edba6b61d5386b11999
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/searchlight refs/changes/65/318365/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: --- prelude: > The initial mitaka release (0.2) did not support ElasticSearch 2.x. ElasticSearch made several changes to index and API requirements that were not backwards compatible with ElasticSearch 1.x. This release has all the changes required for Searchlight to support both ElasticSearch 1.x and 2.x. upgrade: - To support ElasticSearch 1.x and 2.x, several data mappings have been updated. If you previously deployed Searchlight, you will need to reindex your data, specically OS::Nova::Server, OS::Glance::Image, OS::Glance::Metadef, OS::Cinder:Volume, & OS::Cinder::Snapshot. You may also just reindex everything using `searchlight-manage index sync` fixes: - Bug 1570213 Apply query to highlight query - Bug 1532010 Ensure consistency in mapping field types - Bug 1570674 Fix unicode error when booting instance from volume - Bug 1570199 Fix inconsistent mapping in image plugin - Bug 1568709 Remove port.create.end handler from nova - Bug 1565015 Add volume.retype event - Bug 1570213 Apply query to highlight query

commit_message:
sqlalchemy: retry on deadlocks in get_resource()

oslo_db.exception.DBDeadlock: (psycopg2.extensions.TransactionRollbackError) deadlock detected
LINE 3: FROM resource JOIN rt_38f561d4f58747a3a256b2aad624e2b7 ON re...
             ^
DETAIL:  Process 19631 waits for AccessShareLock on relation 16425 of database 12066; blocked by process 19645.
Process 19645 waits for AccessExclusiveLock on relation 16441 of database 12066; blocked by process 19649.
Process 19649 waits for AccessExclusiveLock on relation 16425 of database 12066; blocked by process 19631.

commit_message:
sqlalchemy: avoid deadlock on list_metrics()

oslo_db.exception.DBDeadlock: (psycopg2.extensions.TransactionRollbackError) deadlock detected
LINE 2: ...name = metric.archive_policy_name LEFT OUTER JOIN resource A...
                                                             ^
DETAIL:  Process 19529 waits for AccessShareLock on relation 16425 of database 12066; blocked by process 19569.
Process 19569 waits for AccessExclusiveLock on relation 16441 of database 12066; blocked by process 19572.
Process 19572 waits for AccessExclusiveLock on relation 16425 of database 12066; blocked by process 19529.
HINT:  See server log for query details.
 [SQL: 'SELECT metric.id AS metric_id, metric.archive_policy_name AS metric_archive_policy_name, metric.created_by_user_id AS metric_created_by_user_id, metric.created_by_project_id AS metric_created_by_project_id, metric.resource_id AS metric_resource_id, metric.name AS metric_name, metric.status AS metric_status, archive_policy_1.name AS archive_policy_1_name, archive_policy_1.back_window AS archive_policy_1_back_window, archive_policy_1.definition AS archive_policy_1_definition, archive_policy_1.aggregation_methods AS archive_policy_1_aggregation_methods, resource_1.created_by_user_id AS resource_1_created_by_user_id, resource_1.created_by_project_id AS resource_1_created_by_project_id, resource_1.started_at AS resource_1_started_at, resource_1.revision_start AS resource_1_revision_start, resource_1.ended_at AS resource_1_ended_at, resource_1.user_id AS resource_1_user_id, resource_1.project_id AS resource_1_project_id, resource_1.original_resource_id AS resource_1_original_resource_id, resource_1.id AS resource_1_id, resource_1.type AS resource_1_type \nFROM metric LEFT OUTER JOIN archive_policy AS archive_policy_1 ON archive_policy_1.name = metric.archive_policy_name LEFT OUTER JOIN resource AS resource_1 ON resource_1.id = metric.resource_id AND metric.status = %(status_1)s \nWHERE metric.status = %(status_2)s AND metric.id = %(id_1)s ORDER BY metric.id'] [parameters: {'status_2': 'active', 'id_1': UUID('5c6b89cc-81a9-4dab-adc1-f015903531a2'), 'status_1': 'active'}]

Change-Id: I6531af9fbe0849b4e1b2721b5f4c47a7ac0e7e6e

commit_message:
sqlalchemy: retry on deadlock for create_metric()

oslo_db.exception.DBDeadlock: (psycopg2.extensions.TransactionRollbackError) deadlock detected
DETAIL:  Process 16288 waits for RowShareLock on relation 21012 of database 12066; blocked by process 16284.
Process 16284 waits for AccessExclusiveLock on relation 21050 of database 12066; blocked by process 16295.
Process 16295 waits for AccessExclusiveLock on relation 21012 of database 12066; blocked by process 16288.
HINT:  See server log for query details.
 [SQL: 'INSERT INTO metric (id, archive_policy_name, created_by_user_id, created_by_project_id, resource_id, name) VALUES (%(id)s, %(archive_policy_name)s, %(created_by_user_id)s, %(created_by_project_id)s, %(resource_id)s, %(name)s)'] [parameters: {'resource_id': None, 'id': UUID('467254d2-fb1d-408d-981c-6bb7a9b998b4'), 'name': None, 'archive_policy_name': 'low', 'created_by_user_id': '9f21d34f-d7dc-4613-8e84-d460be32ae68', 'created_by_project_id': '8279bb8f-12fa-4fff-b85a-9fd0773c2545'}]

Change-Id: I22534dd8484caeadef98d45d3c297c01a98d2db3

commit_message:
Don't use cached overcloud image on instack-undercloud patches

instack-undercloud contains elements that may be used to build the
overcloud image, so if an instack-undercloud patch is being tested we
should not use the cached overcloud image.

Change-Id: I84c93c3d6213f5f07d07bb6746c18e2dc928976b
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/tripleo-ci refs/changes/23/320023/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

commit_message:
Initial commit to enable mitaka>newton upgrades

This commit imports much of the documentation, scripts, and
playbooks from the Liberty>Mitaka upgrade process and
applies the appropriate series name changes.

Implements: blueprint upgrade-mitaka-newton
Change-Id: If8e43f1549e6fd121eae7b8d98d8cb16b01e2aab
Signed-off-by: Kevin Carter <kevin.carter@rackspace.com>
(cherry picked from commit 5a09cb7c8dac51788686c5effbec50568293447d)

is built by an openstack contributor (apuimedo

It can be used with:
   vagrant plugin install vagrant-libvirt
   vagrant up --provider libvirt

You can fix the provider in your system by adding to /etc/profile
   export VAGRANT_DEFAULT_PROVIDER=libvirt

And enable kvm nested virtualization by:

   sudo sh \
    -c "echo 'options kvm-intel nested=y' >> /etc/modprobe.d/dist.conf"
   sudo modprobe kvm-intel

Change-Id: I604523e6bc247edee480e881db4e66f3df039af3
'}]
commit_message:
Add libvirt provider support

Add libvirt provider support, the image, although non ubuntu official,
is built by an openstack contributor (apuimedo

It can be used with:
   vagrant plugin install vagrant-libvirt
   vagrant up --provider libvirt

You can fix the provider in your system by adding to /etc/profile
   export VAGRANT_DEFAULT_PROVIDER=libvirt

And enable kvm nested virtualization by:
   sudo rmmod kvm-intel
   sudo sh \
    -c "echo 'options kvm-intel nested=y' >> /etc/modprobe.d/dist.conf"
   sudo modprobe kvm-intel

Change-Id: I604523e6bc247edee480e881db4e66f3df039af3

subject: DevStack: Support setting default quotas
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2016-05-23 13:17:42.000000000', 'files': ['devstack/plugin.sh', 'devstack/settings'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/designate/commit/2bcf3818bbabfa15212b7fc97bd8f84b5f38e2c0', 'message': 'DevStack: Support setting default quotas

As tempest is creating and deleting zones, it does not wait
for all zones to be deleted before moving onto the next test.

This can lead to having a large number of pending delete zones
which consume all/most of the default quotas, and tests begin
failing.

By setting the default quotas higher in DevStack, we allow the
tests to proceed.

Change-Id: I3652bb06724fb8b89bb341c9d9f61b1dde056119
'}]
commit_message:
DevStack: Support setting default quotas

As tempest is creating and deleting zones, it does not wait
for all zones to be deleted before moving onto the next test.

This can lead to having a large number of pending delete zones
which consume all/most of the default quotas, and tests begin
failing.

By setting the default quotas higher in DevStack, we allow the
tests to proceed.

Change-Id: I3652bb06724fb8b89bb341c9d9f61b1dde056119
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/designate refs/changes/29/319929/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # Quota Options DESIGNATE_QUOTA_ZONES=${DESIGNATE_QUOTA_ZONES:-100} DESIGNATE_QUOTA_ZONE_RECORDSETS=${DESIGNATE_QUOTA_ZONE_RECORDSETS:-500} DESIGNATE_QUOTA_ZONE_RECORDS=${DESIGNATE_QUOTA_ZONE_RECORDS:-500} DESIGNATE_QUOTA_RECORDSET_RECORDS=${DESIGNATE_QUOTA_RECORDSET_RECORDS:-20} DESIGNATE_QUOTA_API_EXPORT_SIZE=${DESIGNATE_QUOTA_API_EXPORT_SIZE:-1000}

commit_message:
Add a test case for rebuild of instances with volumes

1. Boot a new instance.
2. Create a new volume.
3. Attach the volume to the instance.
4. Rebuild the server using an alternative image.
5. Check that volume is still attached to the instance.
6. Detach the volume and delete it.
7. Delete the server.

Related-Bug: #1440762

Co-Authored-By: Marian Horban <mhorban@mirantis.com>

Change-Id: I50557c69b54003d3409c8e977966f5332f4fe690
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/tempest refs/changes/49/175949/15 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: @test.attr(type='gate') @test.idempotent_id('b68bd8d6-855d-4212-b59b-2e704044dace') def test_rebuild_server_with_a_volume_attached(self): volume = self.volumes_client.create_volume(size=1) self.volumes_client.wait_for_volume_status(volume['id'], 'available') self.client.attach_volume(self.server_id, volume['id']) self.volumes_client.wait_for_volume_status(volume['id'], 'in-use') try: self.test_rebuild_server() finally: self.client.detach_volume(self.server_id, volume['id']) self.volumes_client.wait_for_volume_status(volume['id'], 'available') self.volumes_client.delete_volume(volume['id'])

Change-Id: Iee7137904d5e4bdc9d6911542a9a8e8fb6995400
'}]
commit_message:
Correct brick-cinderclient-ext functional job node

The gate-brick-cinderclient-ext-dsvm-functional job was instantiated
with a node parameter of "devstack-trusty" (which no longer exists).
Correct this to use our modern "ubuntu-trusty" nodes.

Change-Id: Iee7137904d5e4bdc9d6911542a9a8e8fb6995400
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/project-config refs/changes/33/318333/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: node: ubuntu-trusty

commit_message:
Use ansible-lint 2.7.0

ansible-lint 2.7.0 was recently released, update the role's test
requirements to use it.

The tox test has been changed to run ansible-lint against this role,
rather than the test playbook which would only apply to this role's
dependencies.

Also update the 'Drop fernet key auto rotate script' task to use mode
"0755", matching the comment above the task and to resolve a violation
of new rule, [ANSIBLE0009] Octal file permissions must contain leading
zero.

Change-Id: I09396f8938cf8f0b5d48bc5b7215ecea2c426e94
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/openstack-ansible-os_keystone refs/changes/29/318429/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: ansible-lint {toxinidir}

commit_message:
Switch octavia to oslo

The db, policy and logging options are configured
using puppet oslo module.

Additional changes:

* add dependencies and version of oslo package in
  metadata.json file
* update related unit test
* remove useless parameters

Change-Id: Id252d6043daefb38e934df964755ac6b2efb44ff

commit_message:
Change is_network_endpoint_enabled() to is_service_available()

No need for this to be Netowrk API specific.  The ClientManager
subclass in OSC can wrap this for compatability during the transition.

Change-Id: I325b440364bd530e40d5a6ce26e8014826b7ad5d
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/osc-lib refs/changes/96/320096/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: def is_service_available(self, service_type): """Check if a service type is in the current Service Catalog""" # Trigger authentication necessary to discover endpoint service_available = None if service_catalog: if service_type in service_catalog.get_endpoints(): service_available = True LOG.debug("%s endpoint in service catalog", service_type) else: service_available = False LOG.debug("No %s endpoint in service catalog", service_type) else: LOG.debug("No service catalog") return service_available
deleted_lines: def is_network_endpoint_enabled(self): """Check if the network endpoint is enabled""" # Trigger authentication necessary to determine if the network # endpoint is enabled. network_endpoint_enabled = True if service_catalog: if 'network' in service_catalog.get_endpoints(): LOG.debug("Network endpoint in service catalog") else: LOG.debug("No network endpoint in service catalog") network_endpoint_enabled = False else: LOG.debug("No service catalog, assuming network endpoint enabled") return network_endpoint_enabled

commit_message:
Add support for dry-run deployment without actual graph execution

This patch allows for astute to receive 'dry_run' option in deployment
message and skip actual graph execution. This makes it easier for Fuel
users to execut particular deployment and see the resulting expanded
deployment graph.

Change-Id: I28f216522fbeba9663d836b3d5a2f64c51133238
Partial-bug: #1569839
(cherry picked from commit 94c96e3582beac0a7dab5e699f480a63b3c4f1e0)
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/fuel-astute refs/changes/51/319851/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: tasks_directory: deployment_options[:tasks_directory], dry_run: deployment_options.fetch(:dry_run, false)

subject: Fix bug Swift ACL which disappears on Glance v1 images
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2016-05-24 17:41:56.000000000', 'files': ['glance/api/v1/images.py'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/glance/commit/38a7447770b9e4a6895ceb6135544638a5e72119', 'message': 'Fix bug Swift ACL which disappears on Glance v1 images

Currently, when we make an update on a public image, Swift ACL disappears.
This patch allows to set ACL well when an update on a Glance image is made.
If an update is made on a Glance image without changing the public attribute,
then the function which modifies ACLS is called with the former attribute,
in order to keep ACLS.

Closes-Bug: 1584076

Change-Id: I19bdecb5d30926f3049cfc60641f0eb73b7398e1
'}]
commit_message:
Fix bug Swift ACL which disappears on Glance v1 images

Currently, when we make an update on a public image, Swift ACL disappears.
This patch allows to set ACL well when an update on a Glance image is made.
If an update is made on a Glance image without changing the public attribute,
then the function which modifies ACLS is called with the former attribute,
in order to keep ACLS.

Closes-Bug: 1584076

Change-Id: I19bdecb5d30926f3049cfc60641f0eb73b7398e1
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/glance refs/changes/95/320595/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: is_public = orig_image_meta['is_public']

commit_message:
WIP: First scenario test

This test performs a backup followed by a restore and compares
the restored data with the original data.

Implements bp: freezer-integration-tests

Change-Id: Ia64e283d795c869b4cf21a3c1fb4f80a0118d06b
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/freezer-api refs/changes/51/319351/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # (C) Copyright 2016 Hewlett Packard Enterprise Development Company LP # # Licensed under the Apache License, Version 2.0 (the "License"); you may # not use this file except in compliance with the License. You may obtain # a copy of the License at # # http://www.apache.org/licenses/LICENSE-2.0 # # Unless required by applicable law or agreed to in writing, software # distributed under the License is distributed on an "AS IS" BASIS, WITHOUT # WARRANTIES OR CONDITIONS OF ANY KIND, either express or implied. See the # License for the specific language governing permissions and limitations # under the License. import hashlib import json import os import shutil import tempfile import re import time import subprocess from freezer_api.tests.freezer_api_tempest_plugin.tests.api import base from tempest import test from tempest.lib.cli import base as cli_base from tempest.lib.cli import output_parser # class BaseFreezerCliTest(tempest.test.BaseTestCase): class BaseFreezerCliTest(test.BaseTestCase): """Base test case class for all Freezer API tests.""" credentials = ['primary'] @classmethod def setup_clients(cls): super(BaseFreezerCliTest, cls).setup_clients() uri = cls.os_primary.auth_provider.auth_client.auth_url[:-len('/tokens')] cls.cli = CLIClientWithFreezer( username = cls.os_primary.credentials.credentials.username, password = cls.os_primary.credentials.credentials.password, tenant_name = cls.os_primary.credentials.credentials.tenant_name, uri = uri, cli_dir = '/usr/local/bin' # devstack default ) def delete_job(self, job_id): self.cli.freezer_scheduler(action='job-delete', flags='-c test_node -j {}'.format(job_id)) def create_job(self, job_json): with tempfile.NamedTemporaryFile(delete=False) as job_file: job_file.write(json.dumps(job_json)) job_file.flush() output = self.cli.freezer_scheduler(action='job-create', flags='-c test_node --file {}'.format(job_file.name)) self.assertTrue(output.startswith('Created job')) job_id = output[len('Created job '):] self.addCleanup(self.delete_job, job_id) return job_id def find_job_in_job_list(self, job_id): job_list = output_parser.table(self.cli.freezer_scheduler(action='job-list', flags='-c test_node')) for row in job_list['values']: if row[0].strip() == job_id.strip(): return row self.fail('Could not find job: {}'.format(job_id)) def wait_for_job_status(self, job_id, status, timeout=120): start = time.time() while True: row = self.find_job_in_job_list(job_id) if row[3] == status: return elif time.time() - start > timeout: self.fail("Status of job '{}' is '{}'. Expected '{}'.".format(job_id, row[3], status)) else: time.sleep(1) class CLIClientWithFreezer(cli_base.CLIClient): def freezer_scheduler(self, action, flags='', params='', fail_ok=False, endpoint_type='publicURL', merge_stderr=False): """Executes freezer-scheduler command for the given action. :param action: the cli command to run using freezer-scheduler :type action: string :param flags: any optional cli flags to use :type flags: string :param params: any optional positional args to use :type params: string :param fail_ok: if True an exception is not raised when the cli return code is non-zero :type fail_ok: boolean :param endpoint_type: the type of endpoint for the service :type endpoint_type: string :param merge_stderr: if True the stderr buffer is merged into stdout :type merge_stderr: boolean """ flags += ' --os-endpoint-type %s' % endpoint_type return self.cmd_with_auth( 'freezer-scheduler', action, flags, params, fail_ok, merge_stderr) # This class is just copied from the freezer repo. Depending on where the # scenario tests end up we may need to refactore this. class Temp_Tree(object): def __init__(self, suffix='', dir=None, create=True): self.create = create if create: self.path = tempfile.mkdtemp(dir=dir, prefix='__freezer_', suffix=suffix) else: self.path = dir self.files = [] def __enter__(self): return self def cleanup(self): if self.create and self.path: shutil.rmtree(self.path) def __exit__(self, exc_type, exc_val, exc_tb): self.cleanup() def add_random_data(self, ndir=5, nfile=5, size=1024): """ add some files containing randoma data :param ndir: number of dirs to create :param nfile: number of files to create in each dir :param size: size of files :return: None """ for x in range(ndir): subdir_path = tempfile.mkdtemp(dir=self.path) for y in range(nfile): abs_pathname = self.create_file_with_random_data( dir_path=subdir_path, size=size) rel_path_name = abs_pathname[len(self.path)+1:] self.files.append(rel_path_name) def create_file_with_random_data(self, dir_path, size=1024): handle, abs_pathname = tempfile.mkstemp(dir=dir_path) with open(abs_pathname, 'wb') as fd: fd.write(os.urandom(size)) return abs_pathname def get_file_hash(self, rel_filepath): filepath = os.path.join(self.path, rel_filepath) if os.path.isfile(filepath): return self._filehash(filepath) else: return '' def _filehash(self, filepath): """ Get GIT style sha1 hash for a file :param filepath: path of file to hash :return: hash of the file """ filesize_bytes = os.path.getsize(filepath) hash_obj = hashlib.sha1() hash_obj.update(("blob %u\0" % filesize_bytes).encode('utf-8')) with open(filepath, 'rb') as handle: hash_obj.update(handle.read()) return hash_obj.hexdigest() def get_file_list(self): """ walks the dir tree and creates a list of relative pathnames :return: list of relative file paths """ self.files = [] for root, dirs, files in os.walk(self.path): rel_base = root[len(self.path)+1:] self.files.extend([os.path.join(rel_base, x) for x in files]) return self.files def is_equal(self, other_tree): """ Checks whether two dir tree contain the same files It checks the number of files and the hash of each file. NOTE: tox puts .coverage files in the temp folder (?) :param other_tree: dir tree to compare with :return: true if the dir trees contain the same files """ lh_files = [x for x in sorted(self.get_file_list()) if not x.startswith('.coverage')] rh_files = [x for x in sorted(other_tree.get_file_list()) if not x.startswith('.coverage')] if lh_files != rh_files: return False for fname in lh_files: if os.path.isfile(fname): if self.get_file_hash(fname) != \ other_tree.get_file_hash(fname): return False return True class TestFreezerScenario(BaseFreezerCliTest): def setUp(self): super(TestFreezerScenario, self).setUp() self.source_tree = Temp_Tree() self.source_tree.add_random_data() self.dest_tree = Temp_Tree() self.cli.freezer_scheduler(action='start', flags='-c test_node') def tearDown(self): super(TestFreezerScenario, self).tearDown() self.source_tree.cleanup() self.dest_tree.cleanup() self.cli.freezer_scheduler(action='stop', flags='-c test_node') def test_simple_backup(self): backup_job = { "job_actions": [ { "freezer_action": { "action": "backup", "mode": "fs", "backup_name": "backup1", "path_to_backup": self.source_tree.path, "container": "freezer_test", }, "max_retries": 3, "max_retries_interval": 60 } ], "description": "a test backup" } restore_job = { "job_actions": [ { "freezer_action": { "action": "restore", "restore_abs_path": self.dest_tree.path, "backup_name": "backup1", "container": "freezer_test", }, "max_retries": 3, "max_retries_interval": 60 } ], "description": "a test restore" } backup_job_id = self.create_job(backup_job) self.wait_for_job_status(backup_job_id, 'completed') restore_job_id = self.create_job(restore_job) self.wait_for_job_status(restore_job_id, 'completed') self.assertTrue(self.source_tree.is_equal(self.dest_tree))

commit_message:
Add br_netfilter to 16.04 for support

The 16.04 OS has acceess to the br_netfilter module in kernel ">=4.4" and
must be loaded to allow for bridge tunning. Without the module the following
error happens in subsequent playbook calls: [0]

[0] - http://cdn.pasteraw.com/prrnxqv7lz880g7kuv8040kmtefz6sd

Change-Id: I526c0f9bd082a441f9f49e8ba64a5bcc74317340
Signed-off-by: Kevin Carter <kevin.carter@rackspace.com>
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/openstack-ansible-openstack_hosts refs/changes/39/320139/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: - "{% if hostvars[inventory_hostname]['ansible_kernel'] | version_compare('4.3', '<') %}br_netfilter{% endif %}"

commit_message:
Upgrade JS libraries

LoDash 3.10.1 to 4.13.0
Backbone 1.2 to 1.3.3
Babel modules to 6.9.0 or latest available
Webpack from 0.12 to 0.13

Change-Id: Id77c6cb2f32ada94dba7a0cd3b61d33eeccf90aa

commit_message:
Removing the `verbose` variable

Debug logging enabled by using the `debug` variable should
be sufficient for troubleshooting purposes.

The default logging level has increased from -v to -vv

Change-Id: Iad6785f1b445703fcfd84a5582ca81849d70ceed

commit_message:
Fix tox errors and warnings in the devref

Formatting errors have crept into the manila devref
and have been accumulating over time. It would
be nice to fix these as part of the devref cleanup.

Closes-Bug: #1583850
Partially-implements: bp improve-manila-developer-docs
Change-Id: I7ec954e720b4b88a21e265cd71ea598ea9a5213b

commit_message:
Cleanup 'implied roles' section of Identity API V3 spec

Replace 'link' with 'links'
Cleanup comma usage
Cleanup brace indentation and placement
Remove incorrect extra 'links'
Ensure that the output for GET implied role is wrapped in 'role_inference'

Change-Id: Ie6787c1d81a0fa20bcd4f883b68d15fda7e6ca2f
Closes-Bug: 1563113

commit_message:
Avoid starting serial console workers while deleting vm files

If an instance destroy request is received really quick after it was
powered on, this can fail, having the console log files in use.

This can happen if the instance power on event is received after the
destroy operation has started, which will spawn serial console workers
after the destroy operation tries to clean them up.

We can avoid this situation by simply ensuring that while we delete
the instance log files, the serial console workers are stopped and
no other workers will be spawned.

Change-Id: I3759b557d735cde4391f94819a32994dfb184702
Closes-Bug: #1556189

[{'number': 1, 'created': '2016-03-17 10:36:28.000000000', 'files': ['hyperv/tests/unit/test_migrationops.py', 'hyperv/nova/migrationops.py'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/compute-hyperv/commit/7fb627c317d93b041b76263740f5729dade05b39', 'message': 'hyper-v: Copies back files on failed migration

commit_message:
hyper-v: Copies back files on failed migration

On cold migration, the contents of the instance folder are
copied to the new host. The original folder cannot be removed
because the VM configuration files cannot be deleted until the VM
is destroyed.

Because of this, when the migration fails to copy the files, it will
try to revert this through folder renaming. Since the original folder
still exists, an exception is raised.

Change-Id: Ia42ed873924999d57336a105bcaa2b856f3a3a9d
Closes-Bug: #1555699

commit_message:
Fix unit test for new list of icmpv6 allowed_types

But, we now have accept and reject rules for 134. Was this change to the
list correct?  IPv6 types need to take a look at this.

Closes-bug: #1585022
Change-Id: Icc408a2ca3121f32e605ce612dcc07905a069cd5

[{'number': 1, 'created': '2016-03-03 11:30:45.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/fuel-library/commit/d2239b34d6925f75c895589384a3704c06e25720', 'message': 'Timeout variable and finite number of checks were added to mysql_start

"If there is one cloned mysql instance not starting, the
whole pacemaker cluster gets stuck and does not emit any log. On the
host of the failed instance, I can see a mysql resource agent process
calling the sleep command."

To solve this problem the number of checks that server came up after
starting mysql was bounded in mysql_start method of MySQL RA OCF.
Also there was added the startup timeout variable.

'}, {'number': 16, 'created': '2016-05-24 10:06:20.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/fuel-library/commit/6eedd6730447b85038b13fbdf3038314d72859e5', 'message': 'MySQL OCF stop, start timeout, finite number of checks

"If there is one cloned mysql instance not starting, the
whole pacemaker cluster gets stuck and does not emit any log. On the
host of the failed instance, I can see a mysql resource agent process
calling the sleep command."

To solve this problem:
* bound the number of checks that server either came up or
  established SST after starting.
* add the startup timeout variable that keeps the backwards compatible
  mode, which is wait for ever (-1).
* for the default wait-for-ever case, when mysqld neither came up not
  started SST on start, stop the mysqld process as well.
* fix action stop to consider MySQL not running if only there is no
  SST and no pid found.
* fix proc_stop command to match mysqld by its datadir, fix its stop
  retry count and wait timeout

Closes-bug: #1449542
Closes-bug: #1585125
Co-authored-by: Bogdan Dobrelia <bdobrelia@mirantis.com>

Change-Id: I0789d5aedfa6d8e0592881b073e0ae4b8ac0d1fe
'}, {'number': 17, 'created': '2016-05-24 14:37:32.000000000', 'files': ['files/fuel-ha-utils/ocf/mysql-wss'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/fuel-library/commit/6c685d322ecf0b915e70b0fcca688725207f2b48', 'message': 'MySQL OCF stop check for sst as well

Fix action stop to consider MySQL not running if only there is no

retry count and wait timeout

Closes-bug: #1585125
Change-Id: I0789d5aedfa6d8e0592881b073e0ae4b8ac0d1fe
'}]
commit_message:
MySQL OCF stop check for sst as well

Fix action stop to consider MySQL not running if only there is no
SST and no pid found.
Fix proc_stop command to match mysqld by its datadir, fix its stop
retry count and wait timeout

Closes-bug: #1585125
Change-Id: I0789d5aedfa6d8e0592881b073e0ae4b8ac0d1fe
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/fuel-library refs/changes/33/287733/17 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: OCF_RESKEY_startup_timeout_default="900": ${OCF_RESKEY_startup_timeout=${OCF_RESKEY_startup_timeout_default}} <parameter name="startup_timeout" unique="0" required="0"> <longdesc lang="en"> How long in seconds to wait for confirmation of server startup. If the server does not start within this time, mysql server exits with an error. A value of 0 means not to wait at all for startup. Negative values mean to wait forever (no timeout). </longdesc> <shortdesc lang="en">Startup timeout parameter to pass to mysqld</shortdesc> <content type="integer" default="${OCF_RESKEY_startup_timeout_default}"/> </parameter> local loglevel="warn" local check_server_count=${1:-10} local sleeptime=${2:-3} --user=$OCF_RESKEY_user \ --service-startup-timeout=$OCF_RESKEY_startup_timeout $OCF_RESKEY_additional_parameters \ while [ $check_server_count -gt 0 ]; do check_server_count=$(( check_server_count-1 )) sleep $sleeptime if [ $count -eq 0 ]; then ocf_log $loglevel "${LH} Server didn't come up after starting MySQL" return $OCF_NOT_RUNNING; fi

commit_message:
Add configuration of ovs plugin

Change-Id: Iac96f1e86b9a55aee4c750e638d0c98541f15ea4
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/puppet-monasca refs/changes/58/320158/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # == Class: monasca::checks::ovs # # Sets up the monasca open vswitch check. # # === Parameters # # [*admin_user*] # name of the monasca admin # # [*admin_password*] # password for the monasca admin # # [*admin_tenant_name*] # name of the monasca admin tenant/project # # [*identity_uri*] # uri of the keystone instance # # [*region_name*] # openstack keystone region for this install # # [*cache_dir*] # Cache directory to persist data. # # [*neutron_refresh*] # Interval to force data refresh from neutron. # # [*check_router_ha*] # Flag to indicate if additional neutron calls should be # made to determine if an HA router is active or standby. # # [*network_use_bits*] # Flag to indicate bits should be reported instead of # bytes. # # [*ovs_cmd*] # Command to run to get ovs data. # class monasca::checks::ovs( $admin_user = undef, $admin_password = undef, $admin_tenant_name = undef, $cache_dir = '/dev/shm', $check_router_ha = 'true', $identity_uri = undef, $network_use_bits = 'true', $neutron_refresh = '14400', $ovs_cmd = 'sudo /usr/bin/ovs-vsctl', $region_name = undef, ){ $conf_dir = $::monasca::agent::conf_dir File["${conf_dir}/ovs.yaml"] ~> Service['monasca-agent'] file { "${conf_dir}/ovs.yaml": owner => 'root', group => $::monasca::group, mode => '0640', content => template('monasca/checks/ovs.yaml.erb'), require => File[$conf_dir], } }
